items.message: Sea spray overtopping is forecast along the coast as a result of high spring tides.  Forecast high water is 08:30 on 05/03/22 with a level of 6.30 mAOD and a Force 5 Northerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 05/03/22 high tide at 20:45. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Saturday, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.71mAOD at 16:45 on 05/03/22 and 4.76mAOD at 05:00 on 06/03/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 130 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 2.83m on Friday; Cae Howel 3.4 to 3.5m today, Saturday 05/03/22. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels are rising following recent rainfall in the Yorkshire Dales. River levels are beginning to reach their peak and will begin to slowly fall this afternoon, Saturday 5th March. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible on Saturday 05/03/2022. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. There is no significant rainfall forecast over the coming days. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels are rising on the River Ouse due to recent rainfall in the Yorkshire Dales. River levels are beginning to reach their peak and will begin to slowly fall this afternoon, Saturday 5th March. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We will continue to monitor levels closely. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall over the past few days. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues today, Saturday 05/03/2022. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  River levels have peaked and will remain steady, before starting to fall during the day.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated this evening, 05/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high but steady at the Tern - Walcot and Rodington river gauges following recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 06/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and steadily at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue through today, 05/03/2022, into tomorrow morning, 06/03/2022. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame following rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially close to the river around Dorchester-on-Thames, Thame and Stadhampton. We are expecting a mostly dry day, with the potential for a few scattered showers later this afternoon/evening (Saturday 5th March). River levels are now stable but we expect them to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.8m to 3.1m 06/03/22 on Sunday morning, Haw Bridge 3.9m to 4.1m 05/03/22 on Saturday overnight into Sunday, Sandhurst 3.5m to 3.7m on 05/03/22 at 23:45, Gloucester 3.3m to 3.5m 05/03/22 at 23:30.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides combined with high fluvial river levels will be at their highest between 23:30 Saturday, 05/03/22 and 00:30 Sunday, 06/03/22 and 12:00 and 13:00 Sunday, 06/03/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations affected; low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.5m to 3.7m 05/03/22 at 23:45 and 3.3m to 3.6m on 06/03/22 at 12:00, Gloucester 3.3m to 3.5m 05/03/22 at 23:30 and 3.4m to 3.6m 06/03/22 at 12:00. Flooding is not expected at other tidal gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding is possible on high tides at 11:00 and 23:30 on 05/03/22 at Torksey. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 23:30 on 05/03/22 at Torksey. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and rising very slowly at the Burcote river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River from Crackley Bank to Bridgnorth. Other locations that may be affected include Ryton and Burcote. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday, 06/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this evening the 5th March at 5:15 pm and is forecast to reach approximately 5.00-5.10 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected at 5:30 am tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5.00-5.15 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides this evening and tomorrow morning. 
This message will be updated this evening, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high but steady at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 05/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes. Further light rainfall is forecast today, Saturday 05/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Saturday, 05/03/22. This information is correct as of 15:40 on Saturday 05 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 22 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow morning, 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 05/03/22. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault. Further light rainfall is forecast today, Saturday 05/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Saturday, 05/03/2022. This information is correct as of 15:40 on Saturday 05 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 22 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow morning, 06/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.
River levels on the Chertsey Bourne are continuing to fall slowly, but remain high in some locations in Chertsey. Continued flooding of some low lying land and roads in isolated locations in Chertsey is still possible this morning, 05/03/22. However river levels are expected to continue to fall throughout the day and we may be able to remove this Flood Alert later today. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated by this evening, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further light rainfall is forecast today, Saturday 05/03/22. River levels may rise again in response to this rainfall and we will reissue this flood alert if necessary.   
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.    
We continue to monitor the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.   Further rainfall is forecast tonight, Friday 04/03/22, and tomorrow, Saturday 05/03/22. River levels may rise again in response to this rainfall and we will reissue this flood alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels on the Lower River Loddon remain high but are falling slowly and the river is flowing within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding isn’t currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Flooding is no longer expected. 
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides at 5:15 pm today (05/03/22) and 5:30 am tomorrow, but flooding of low lying land, roads and footpaths from these high tides is no longer expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
